pros: Great group of people, flexible working, lots of training and development opportunities
cons: Pay is low but made up for by the benefits and culture

review_title: good relaxed place to work, nice people.
job_title: Lecturer in Warrington, North West England, England
pros: relaxed atmosphere with no micro-managenebnt
cons: no opportunities for promotion within the department

pros: Chester is a beautiful city with a low crime rate. The campuses are small and fairly close to each other. The main campus Exton Park is quite nice, with many facilities and a free swimming pool.
cons: The new VC has this citizen student ideology, which seems to say screw the staff and cater to all the student's whims. There is not enough room on campus for all the staff, so the Faculty of Science and Engineering are just left to rot. Hot desking is their answer, but they've given less than a dozen desks to share - including admin. There are plenty of other hot desk options, but you have to share them with students. Staff numbers are kept short, so expect to teach up to 5 modules with 20-30 hours of teaching between 9am to 7pm. Then prepare to be looked down upon because you've not had time to publish enough journal articles.

pros: Flexi time and home working. Management understanding of outside commitments. Closes over Christmas and new year
cons: Workload increases but the staff don't, people on low levels are expected to be working above their level. Staff not appreciated. Other universities paying more for lower grades

pros: The team were really great
cons: The pay could be better

pros: Flexible Work hours Great team to work with
cons: Goals were sometimes unclear Meetings were at undesirable time for students

pros: Great team, good line management Great pension Lots of overtime if you want it
cons: Shift work Changing management at various levels Communications blockage at some point between staff and smt

review_title: Wouldn’t wish that work environment on anyone
pros: Colleagues across various departments friendly and supportive. Good Diversity festival.
cons:
Very toxic working environment within Registry Services department. Culture of bullying, misogyny and disrespect. No consideration towards staff well-being or mental health (I was signed off for two months with stress and none of the management team contacted me to check in or even respond to emails regarding sick notes). Communication within department is very poor. The first, and only, departmental meeting post-pandemic was held 9 months later (Dec 2020) and and no support was offered to help staff with the transition. Development opportunities restricted and staff not invested in. Training constantly requested but never delivered as senior management are “too busy” to train staff or the team is “too busy” for the manager to permit 1 hour off per month. Heavy restrictions on when annual leave is permitted, disadvantages staff with children in school as it’s 10 weeks over summer. Constantly expected to work overtime as teams are not sufficiently staffed. When issues are raised they are not dealt with or you’re seen as “complaining”. threatened. 

Needless to say, I would never want to work for that department ever again. I’ve since accepted a lower paying job elsewhere to protect my mental health.

pros: Small, quaint university in a historic town.
cons: Limited research opportunities and office spaces for academic staff.

pros: considers sustainability and health and environmental impact
cons: old-school ways of thinking and working and slow to uptake new ideas and methods

pros: Great employer very staff focussed
cons: None - no downsides it is an enjoyable place to work.

cons: Nothing - brilliant experience. Could be more 'UniJob' opportunities (If i had to put something)

review_title: Awful place  resigned after only 3 months
job_title: Fitness Instructor in Warrington, North West England, England
pros: none- didn't offer me any development or opportunities, ignored any ''ideas or brainstorming''
cons: Management are intimidating and overly critical even to their best employees. Since day one of working there I had the feeling I was treading on egg shells. Lots of unhappy staff and scared to to put a foot out of line. Since being laid off due to coronavirus they have refused to Furlough me and many others because ''they are under no obligation to". I am not the only one who didn't/doesnt feel valued as an employee and I hope that the good staff who still work there (my old work friends) find another job as soon as they can!

pros: The hours are good, flexible working hours option, so it has the potential to fit well around your life. Location and facilities are good too. Swimming pool, cheap gym membership for staff. Able to be fairly autonomous within your own work area and set your own goals and targets, fairly relaxed attitude within the offices
cons: Low salary for sector and skills demanded, no training or development, in my opinion  a very poor management structure and communication, there is a distinct lack of experience in "middle" management in the technical departments. It feels very much like stepping back 20 years in my career in terms of approach and attitude, public sector mentality not for everyone but you trade this off for the pros as outlined above

review_title: A good place for starting academics, but maybe don't stay too long
pros: Flexible and friendly work environment, no "ridiculous" academic targets to hit each year. Supportive environment for starting academics, but only if you are in the "right" department. Management can vary vastly across departments and faculties.
cons: Lack of support for research and other scholarly work, less brand power while talking to other universities and companies for collaborations and projects.

pros: innocent  good people there in spite of malevolent agenda
cons: Misogynistic working environment left unchecked. Bloated incompetent Management structure . A culture of  harassment  gossip and false accusation  backed up by HR .  An attitude of condescension to employees.  The modus operandi is to  crush the spirit of  the  employees.   The management structure despises intelligence, honesty and  morality . It is a tragedy that a Christian front is used to foster an extreme intolerant liberalism of laissez faire morality.

pros: Supportive, friendly and professional team. Good working environment. Flexible working patterns, flexi-time and plenty of opportunities to get involved with activities both inside and outside of working hours e.g. sport, yoga, walking clubs. Fair pay in the sense that people doing the same job at same level get paid the same. Also the opportunity to apply for internal job vacancies that aren't advertised to the public.
cons: None really, but a staff area to eat lunch would be nice, rather than sitting at work desks.
